Cranes are compared to ascetics here probably because of the similarity of their posture when relaxing standing on one leg to ascetics performing penance standing on one leg (such as the ascetic, and a cat, depicted on the famous relief in Mahabalipuram).
TEXT: mūtraviṣṭhe na bhūmīṣu kurute śvānadaḥ sadā|
NOTE: A possible expanation for Śiva being satisfied with an ascetic practising this observance is that Śiva's Bhairava form often has a dog as his mount. See, e.g., BakkerWorld2014232--233 on a 5-6th-century image of Bhairava and a dog carved in rock at Muṇḍeśvarı̄ Hill not far from Vārāṇasī, and Mirnig 2013, 334 ?\verify This observance has ancient roots. Its practitioner, the Łkukkuravatika$ appears in Majjhimanikāya 2.1.7, in the Kukkuravatiyasutta, alongside with a practitioner of the Łgovrata$ (Łgovatika$), an observance that comes up in the next verse in the \VSS: Łevaṃ me sutaṃ. ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā koliyesu viharati haliddavasanaṃ nāma koliyānaṃ nigamo. atha kho puṇṇo ca koliyaputto govatiko, acelo ca seniyo kukkuravatiko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu...$ See AcharyaBull127--128. Acharya summarises the Kukkuravatiyasutta thus: `The Kukkuravatiyasutta from the Majjhimanikāya (II.1.7) presents a Łgovatika$ together with a Łkukkuravatika$. They are observing their vows, and have adopted the behaviour of a bull and a dog respectively. The Buddha tells them that as they are cultivating bullness and dogness, the state of mind of these animals, they will go to hell or become reborn as animal. They are alarmed at this and take refuge in the Buddha.'
TEXT: mūtravarco na rudhyeta sadā govratiko naraḥ|
NOTE:
I prefer reading Łbhīma$ and Łtuṣṭi°$ as two separate words, the first one either in stem form (\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msP) or as Łbhīmas$ (\msCc\msNb\Ed) or Łbhīmaṃ$ (\eme), to reading these two words as a compound because of the following Łcaiva$. I suspect that both Łbhīma$ and Łtuṣṭikara$ refer to the Łvrata$, rather than its practitioner, but I have not emended Łbhīmas tuṣṭikaraś$ to Łbhīmaṃ tuṣṭikaraṃ$ because Łvrata$ appears as a masculine noun, e.g., in 8.17d below.
AcharyaBull gives a number of significant clues about the origins of this observance. After exploring its links to Pāśupatas, AcharyaBull116--118, quotes Jaiminīyabrāhmaṇa 2.113, which contains the phrase Łyatra yatrainaṃ viṣṭhā vindet tat tad vitiṣṭheta$, in Acharya's translation: `Wherever he feels the urge to evacuate f\ae ces, right there he should evacuate.' This is an instruction in a Vedic text that is close to what the \VSS\ teaches above. Incidentaly, the Jaiminīyabrāhmaṇa adds: Łtena haitenottaravayasy e$ [Łva$] Łyajeta$ (translated in AcharyaBull118 as: `One should perform this [sacrifice] in the ﬁnal years of one's life').
APP: \va kuddālair{ }dārayanto \msNa\msP\Ed; kuddālair{ }dārayanno \msCa, kuddārai dārayanto \msCb, kudārai dārayantā \msCc, kuddālai ddārayām{ }āsa \msNb, kuddālai dārayanto \msNc
NOTE:
While Łdārayanto$ as an active participle in the masculine nominative is acceptable as an irregular form, the precise interpretation of Łpāda$s a and b is still problematic therefore my translation of this verse is tentative and the description seems too condensed to be intelligible. Kengo Harimoto suggested that \msCc\ and \Ed\ might be transmitting the correct reading, and then the reference would be to soil piled up by millions of insects (Łkīṭakoṭi$°), instead of points of wedges (Łkīlakoṭi$°). Nevertheless, now I think that the reference point could be Bhīṣma's dying scene in the \MBH, where the great warrior is lying on a bed of hundreds of arrows: sa śete śaratalpastho medinīm aspṛśaṃs tadā: `Then he lay there on his bed of arrows, without touching the ground' (\MBH\ 6.115.8ab). The word Łcita$ is used in the same context in \MBH\ 12.47.4ab: vikīrṇāṃśur ivādityo bhīṣmaḥ śaraśataiś citaḥ: `Bhīṣma, laid on a hundred arrows, was like the Sun with its scattered rays of light.' If this interpretation of \VSS\ 8.17 is correct, the observance described here may require one to dig the ground, install wedges, and lie on them, in the manner of fakirs. The reference to the Earth in Łpāda$ c may have been inspired by lines such as \MBH\ 6.115.11cd: rarāsa pṛthivī caiva bhīṣme śāṃtanave hate: `The Earth cried out when Bhīṣma, the son of Śaṃtanu, was killed.'
In \BHAVP\ 4.121, called `The Description of eighty-five observances' (Łvratapañcāśītivarṇana$), we find this on Łmahīvrata$: dadyāt triṃśatpalād ūrdhvaṃ mahīṃ kṛtvā tu kāṃcanīm | kulācalādrisahitāṃ tilavastrasamanvitām || 152 || tiladroṇopari gatāṃ brāhmaṇāya kuṭuṃbine | dinaṃ payovratas tiṣṭhed rudraloke mahīyate || 153 || etan mahīvrataṃ proktaṃ saptakalpānuvartakam |.
A tentative translation of this passage would go as follows: `One should donate a golden [model of] Earth that weighs more than thirty Łpala$s (appr. one kilogram), showing the chief mountain-ranges, together with [donations of] sesamum seeds and clothes, the sesamum seeds [weighing] more than a Łdroṇa$ (appr. ten kilograms), to a householder Brāhmin. One should keep the milk-observance [i.e. subsisting on nothing but milk] for one day, and one will have fun in Rudraloka. This is called the Earth Observance whose range is seven \ae ons.' (I take the values for weights from OlivelleManu997.) The descriptions of the Łdharāvrata$ and the Łśubhadvādaśī$ observance in KaneHistoryv. 5, 321 and 429 are similar. The \VSS's Łmahīvrata$ seems different, and more in line with the somewhat transgressive and wild, perhaps Pāśupata-oriented, nature of the four preceding observances.

The verse may refer to the destruction of Dakṣa's sacrifice, after which the gods were relieved. The Ṛgvedic mantra starting with Łāpo hi ṣṭhā$ (ṚV 10.9.1--3) is traditionally associated with Łmārjana$ (`cleaning, wiping'). According to KaneHistoryv. 4, 120, a Brahmin `should bathe thrice in the day, should perform Łmārjana$ (splashing or sprinkling water on the head and other limbs by means of Łkuśas$ dipped in water after repeating sacred mantras) with the three verses `apo hi sthā' [sic] (Ṛg. X.9.1--3) [...]' This suggests a method of bathing that is more of a ritual than an actual bath.
Understand Łgoṣu$ in Łpāda$ a as Łgavāṃ$ (genitive).
This version of bathing seems to be a way of taking a shower in the holy dust raising from under the hooves of cows.
This verse marks not only the end of a long section on the Niyama rules, but also the end of a major part of the text that discusses the ten Yama and ten Niyama rules, spanning 3.16--8.44.

There are two stem form nouns in Łpāda$ b: I suspect that \Ed\ is right assuming that in order to restore the metre, we must have Łnigadita$ and not Łnigaditas$, which is trasmitted in all the witnesses; also understand Łsarvalokānukampya$ in Łpāda$ b as Łsarvalokān anukampya$.

Understand Łsakalamalapahārī$ in Łpāda$ c as Łsakala-mala-apahārī$, which would be unmetrical, and compare it with Łduritamalapahārī$ in 4.89c. Take Łetan/etad$ as either picking up °Łpahārī$ or rather a plural corresponding to °Łpañcāśad$. The latter phenomenon, namely the use of the singular after numbers, is one of the hallmarks of the text.
By `fifty Dharmas,' the text refers to the ten main Niyama-rules × five subcategories.
The licence of an word-ultimate short syllable treated as long (°Łjanma$ in Łpāda$ d) is also freqently seen here. Note also Łpuna$ for Łpunar$ metri causa.
